abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Third Economic
            Governance Reform Operation Project for Haiti were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, risk to
            development outcome was substantial, Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: Experience
            points to the need for adopting a simple approach in most
            fragile countries, in particular in a country with high risk
            of occurrence of major natural disasters as Haiti. The
            decision to do a single-tranche operation was adequate in
            view of the possible risks affecting the operation, the
            period required by the Government to implement the reforms,
            and the need to test the Government's sustained
            commitment to the reform program. However, in a country with
            an extremely low capacity, there is the need for future
            projects of this kind to specify better the responsibility
            of every agency in achieving the stated objectives.  A key
            immediate challenge for the government was to continue
            strengthening the legal framework for public finance
            management and public procurement to ensure proper
            management of aid inflows. Public expenditure management and
            procurement are of great importance as aid inflows are
            expected for reconstruction programs. This is a lesson drawn
            from experience in post-natural disaster countries. Close
            coordination among development partners within a simple,
            commonly agreed reform’s framework is important. Such an
            approach requires a prioritization of reforms with a
            reasonable milestone framework based on commonly agreed targets.
